post.body:
Well, I'm far enough to have a good number of mapobjects under my belt, but I'm no lightwave authority either.

I end up unwrapping everything manually, even simple objects, because it's the best way (that I know of) to get everything right with a minimal number of seams.

The orientation matters. The text isn't reversed on the model, the UV just isn't oriented in the fashion you want. I seriously believe it's Lightwave's method of unwrapping. Using Atlas might produce better results, since it can go piece by piece that way, but then the skin will have more seams than is required.

This is why I would encourage you to start unwrapping manually. It seems assinine for a cylinder, I know, but the more practice you get in the better off you'll be when you need to skin something more organic.

I use the method described in "approach 2" here: http://www.newtek.com/products/lightwave/tutorials/uvmapping/character_UV/index.html

This method gives you total control over where the seams will be generated (important with bump mapping), as well as how much detail specific parts of your model will be relative to other parts (on a shotgun barrel, for instance, your pixels might be better spent with details along the circumference of the cylinder, as opposed to along the length).

And even if you ultimately go back to using projections for most of your UV maps, practice you get in with this method will help you be more bold when editing your UVs, and help you understand how inverted, rotated, skewed, and scaled triangles will affect your result.

post.body:
Phobos wrote:
...what should I do when I'm looking at the unwrapped model in the uv window, and not all of it fits into the black square? Just move it over, then PrintScreen and do the texture?


Totally! I can't see your mesh in the UV view in that screenshot, but I'm assuming you might also have to scale that part of the model down.

As far as printscreening for the texture...

I assume you're making this model for Doom 3. That's all I model for so my workflow is, as far as I know, the quickest way from nothing to in-game with lightwave. So let me describe how I do it. Not saying your way is wrong, I realize that's the way it's done quite often (or I guess instead of printscreen a modeler more experienced than us might make a quick render in layout using the uv map, but I don't know how to do that).

Step: The First
Anyways, I create the High Poly mesh first. In this mesh I assign up to six different surfaces on the model, based on how I plan to skin it later. I have a Red, Green, and Blue surface with smoothing on (for organics), and Red, Green, and Blue surface with smoothing off (for flat surfaces and harsh angles). There's no need to set the color to actually be red, green, and blue until you're ready to renderbump.

Step: The Second
I create the Low Poly mesh second. It's easy to do with the High Poly mesh in the background. I usually just draw the triangles by hand, with the add points tool, and then selecting points and either making a triangle, quad, triangle fan, or triangle bridge. It's not as fast as merging surfaces, or using qemLOSS2 or a lot of other ways, but it's precise and puts all the right triangles in all the right places.

Step: The Second Jr.
I create a morph map called "flat" and proceed to unwrap my UV map here. This method is described pretty well in that article I linked earlier. When I'm done I use the Planar projection with manual settings. You can usually leave the Center variables alone, but you'll probably want to modify the Size variables so that they're even (i.e. not X of 1.18 m and Y of 1.12, you'd want both to be 1.18 if you're projecting on the Z plane).

Step: His Highness the Third
Let's review what we have.
  1. A high poly mesh with a handful of different colored surfaces.
  2. A low poly mesh with a surface that points to our material and a UV map.
So now we make sure the material we're pointing to has the renderbump command, with "-colormap" specified. Go to Doom3 and renderbump <path_to_low_poly.lwo>.

This should produce a bump map and a color map in the path we specified in the shader. In photoshop I use the bumpmap to discern where the triangles fall (this serves as my mesh view, and it's surprisingly easy to work with), and I use the color map to make quick selections of different parts so that I can, for instance, just select the red channel and use that as a mask on a layer containing a wood texture for the gun's stock, and then select the green channel and use that as a mask on a layer containing metal for the gun's barrel.

Then there's all sorts of voodoo I work for refining the skin, like my tutorial on modwiki where I base the specularmap on the bumpmap to start with.

This is the workflow that has served me best thus far. It's a combination of Goliath's early tutorial with lightwave, id's iddevnet way, and that uv unwrapping article I linked.

Working in earnest, with my modest modeling skills, I can have a near-final model in game in a few hours this way. Albeit, with a rudimentary skin at that point.

post.author: onu
post.body:
If you want a surface to be smooth, make sure you select "smoothing" in the surface editor.

Otherwise you have to subdivide until the triangles are smaller than the pixels on the destination bump map.

Not that I ever did that... >_>

When you want hard edges to these smooth surfaces, create a new surface. Smoothing doesn't occur across surface groups, so you'll have a hard edge there even if both surfaces have smoothing turned on and they are identical in every way.

Another way to get hard edges is to simply unweld points, but that's more cumbersome to work with.

Not saying your way is wrong, I realize that's the way it's done quite often (or I guess instead of printscreen a modeler more experienced than us might make a quick render in layout using the uv map, but I don't know how to do that).

Step: The First
Anyways, I create the High Poly mesh first. In this mesh I assign up to six different surfaces on the model, based on how I plan to skin it later. I have a Red, Green, and Blue surface with smoothing on (for organics), and Red, Green, and Blue surface with smoothing off (for flat surfaces and harsh angles). There's no need to set the color to actually be red, green, and blue until you're ready to renderbump.

Step: The Second
I create the Low Poly mesh second. It's easy to do with the High Poly mesh in the background. I usually just draw the triangles by hand, with the add points tool, and then selecting points and either making a triangle, quad, triangle fan, or triangle bridge. It's not as fast as merging surfaces, or using qemLOSS2 or a lot of other ways, but it's precise and puts all the right triangles in all the right places.

Step: The Second Jr.
I create a morph map called "flat" and proceed to unwrap my UV map here. This method is described pretty well in that article I linked earlier. When I'm done I use the Planar projection with manual settings. You can usually leave the Center variables alone, but you'll probably want to modify the Size variables so that they're even (i.e. not X of 1.18 m and Y of 1.12, you'd want both to be 1.18 if you're projecting on the Z plane).

This should produce a bump map and a color map in the path we specified in the shader. In photoshop I use the bumpmap to discern where the triangles fall (this serves as my mesh view, and it's surprisingly easy to work with), and I use the color map to make quick selections of different parts so that I can, for instance, just select the red channel and use that as a mask on a layer containing a wood texture for the gun's stock, and then select the green channel and use that as a mask on a layer containing metal for the gun's barrel.

Then there's all sorts of voodoo I work for refining the skin, like my tutorial on modwiki where I base the specularmap on the bumpmap to start with.

I assume you're making this model for Doom 3. That's all I model for so my workflow is, as far as I know, the quickest way from nothing to in-game with lightwave. So let me describe how I do it. Not saying your way is wrong, I realize that's the way it's done quite often (or I guess instead of printscreen a modeler more experienced than us might make a quick render in layout using the uv map, but I don't know how to do that).

Step: The First
Anyways, I create the High Poly mesh first. In this mesh I assign up to six different surfaces on the model, based on how I plan to skin it later. I have a Red, Green, and Blue surface with smoothing on (for organics), and Red, Green, and Blue surface with smoothing off (for flat surfaces and harsh angles). There's no need to set the color to actually be red, green, and blue until you're ready to renderbump.

Step: The Second
I create the Low Poly mesh second. It's easy to do with the High Poly mesh in the background. I usually just draw the triangles by hand, with the add points tool, and then selecting points and either making a triangle, quad, triangle fan, or triangle bridge. It's not as fast as merging surfaces, or using qemLOSS2 or a lot of other ways, but it's precise and puts all the right triangles in all the right places.

Step: The Second Jr.
I create a morph map called "flat" and proceed to unwrap my UV map here. This method is described pretty well in that article I linked earlier. When I'm done I use the Planar projection with manual settings. You can usually leave the Center variables alone, but you'll probably want to modify the Size variables so that they're even (i.e. not X of 1.18 m and Y of 1.12, you'd want both to be 1.18 if you're projecting on the Z plane).

Step: His Highness the Third
Let's review what we have.
  1. A high poly mesh with a handful of different colored surfaces.
  2. A low poly mesh with a surface that points to our material and a UV map.
So now we make sure the material we're pointing to has the renderbump command, with "-colormap" specified. Go to Doom3 and renderbump <path_to_low_poly.lwo>.

This should produce a bump map and a color map in the path we specified in the shader. In photoshop I use the bumpmap to discern where the triangles fall (this serves as my mesh view, and it's surprisingly easy to work with), and I use the color map to make quick selections of different parts so that I can, for instance, just select the red channel and use that as a mask on a layer containing a wood texture for the gun's stock, and then select the green channel and use that as a mask on a layer containing metal for the gun's barrel.

Then there's all sorts of voodoo I work for refining the skin, like my tutorial on modwiki where I base the specularmap on the bumpmap to start with.

This is the workflow that has served me best thus far. It's a combination of Goliath's early tutorial with lightwave, id's iddevnet way, and that uv unwrapping article I linked.

post.body:
If you want a surface to be smooth, make sure you select "smoothing" in the surface editor.

Otherwise you have to subdivide until the triangles are smaller than the pixels on the destination bump map.

Not that I ever did that... >_>

When you want hard edges to these smooth surfaces, create a new surface. Smoothing doesn't occur across surface groups, so you'll have a hard edge there even if both surfaces have smoothing turned on and they are identical in every way.

Another way to get hard edges is to simply unweld points, but that's more cumbersome to work with.

I assume you're making this model for Doom 3. That's all I model for so my workflow is, as far as I know, the quickest way from nothing to in-game with lightwave. So let me describe how I do it. Not saying your way is wrong, I realize that's the way it's done quite often (or I guess instead of printscreen a modeler more experienced than us might make a quick render in layout using the uv map, but I don't know how to do that).

Step: The First
Anyways, I create the High Poly mesh first. In this mesh I assign up to six different surfaces on the model, based on how I plan to skin it later. I have a Red, Green, and Blue surface with smoothing on (for organics), and Red, Green, and Blue surface with smoothing off (for flat surfaces and harsh angles). There's no need to set the color to actually be red, green, and blue until you're ready to renderbump.

Step: The Second
I create the Low Poly mesh second. It's easy to do with the High Poly mesh in the background. I usually just draw the triangles by hand, with the add points tool, and then selecting points and either making a triangle, quad, triangle fan, or triangle bridge. It's not as fast as merging surfaces, or using qemLOSS2 or a lot of other ways, but it's precise and puts all the right triangles in all the right places.

Step: The Second Jr.
I create a morph map called "flat" and proceed to unwrap my UV map here. This method is described pretty well in that article I linked earlier. When I'm done I use the Planar projection with manual settings. You can usually leave the Center variables alone, but you'll probably want to modify the Size variables so that they're even (i.e. not X of 1.18 m and Y of 1.12, you'd want both to be 1.18 if you're projecting on the Z plane).

Step: His Highness the Third
Let's review what we have.
  1. A high poly mesh with a handful of different colored surfaces.
  2. A low poly mesh with a surface that points to our material and a UV map.
So now we make sure the material we're pointing to has the renderbump command, with "-colormap" specified. Go to Doom3 and renderbump <path_to_low_poly.lwo>.

This should produce a bump map and a color map in the path we specified in the shader. In photoshop I use the bumpmap to discern where the triangles fall (this serves as my mesh view, and it's surprisingly easy to work with), and I use the color map to make quick selections of different parts so that I can, for instance, just select the red channel and use that as a mask on a layer containing a wood texture for the gun's stock, and then select the green channel and use that as a mask on a layer containing metal for the gun's barrel.

Then there's all sorts of voodoo I work for refining the skin, like my tutorial on modwiki where I base the specularmap on the bumpmap to start with.

This is the workflow that has served me best thus far. It's a combination of Goliath's early tutorial with lightwave, id's iddevnet way, and that uv unwrapping article I linked.

Working in earnest, with my modest modeling skills, I can have a near-final model in game in a few hours this way. Albeit, with a rudimentary skin at that point.

Well, I'm far enough to have a good number of mapobjects under my belt, but I'm no lightwave authority either.

I end up unwrapping everything manually, even simple objects, because it's the best way (that I know of) to get everything right with a minimal number of seams.

The orientation matters. The text isn't reversed on the model, the UV just isn't oriented in the fashion you want. I seriously believe it's Lightwave's method of unwrapping. Using Atlas might produce better results, since it can go piece by piece that way, but then the skin will have more seams than is required.

This is why I would encourage you to start unwrapping manually. It seems assinine for a cylinder, I know, but the more practice you get in the better off you'll be when you need to skin something more organic.

I use the method described in "approach 2" here: http://www.newtek.com/products/lightwave/tutorials/uvmapping/character_UV/index.html

This method gives you total control over where the seams will be generated (important with bump mapping), as well as how much detail specific parts of your model will be relative to other parts (on a shotgun barrel, for instance, your pixels might be better spent with details along the circumference of the cylinder, as opposed to along the length).

And even if you ultimately go back to using projections for most of your UV maps, practice you get in with this method will help you be more bold when editing your UVs, and help you understand how inverted, rotated, skewed, and scaled triangles will affect your result.

As far as printscreening for the texture...

I assume you're making this model for Doom 3. That's all I model for so my workflow is, as far as I know, the quickest way from nothing to in-game with lightwave. So let me describe how I do it. Not saying your way is wrong, I realize that's the way it's done quite often (or I guess instead of printscreen a modeler more experienced than us might make a quick render in layout using the uv map, but I don't know how to do that).

Step: The First
Anyways, I create the High Poly mesh first. In this mesh I assign up to six different surfaces on the model, based on how I plan to skin it later. I have a Red, Green, and Blue surface with smoothing on (for organics), and Red, Green, and Blue surface with smoothing off (for flat surfaces and harsh angles). There's no need to set the color to actually be red, green, and blue until you're ready to renderbump.

Step: The Second
I create the Low Poly mesh second. It's easy to do with the High Poly mesh in the background. I usually just draw the triangles by hand, with the add points tool, and then selecting points and either making a triangle, quad, triangle fan, or triangle bridge. It's not as fast as merging surfaces, or using qemLOSS2 or a lot of other ways, but it's precise and puts all the right triangles in all the right places.

Step: The Second Jr.
I create a morph map called "flat" and proceed to unwrap my UV map here. This method is described pretty well in that article I linked earlier. When I'm done I use the Planar projection with manual settings. You can usually leave the Center variables alone, but you'll probably want to modify the Size variables so that they're even (i.e. not X of 1.18 m and Y of 1.12, you'd want both to be 1.18 if you're projecting on the Z plane).

Step: His Highness the Third
Let's review what we have.
  1. A high poly mesh with a handful of different colored surfaces.
  2. A low poly mesh with a surface that points to our material and a UV map.
So now we make sure the material we're pointing to has the renderbump command, with "-colormap" specified. Go to Doom3 and renderbump <path_to_low_poly.lwo>.

This should produce a bump map and a color map in the path we specified in the shader. In photoshop I use the bumpmap to discern where the triangles fall (this serves as my mesh view, and it's surprisingly easy to work with), and I use the color map to make quick selections of different parts so that I can, for instance, just select the red channel and use that as a mask on a layer containing a wood texture for the gun's stock, and then select the green channel and use that as a mask on a layer containing metal for the gun's barrel.

Then there's all sorts of voodoo I work for refining the skin, like my tutorial on modwiki where I base the specularmap on the bumpmap to start with.

This is the workflow that has served me best thus far. It's a combination of Goliath's early tutorial with lightwave, id's iddevnet way, and that uv unwrapping article I linked.

Working in earnest, with my modest modeling skills, I can have a near-final model in game in a few hours this way. Albeit, with a rudimentary skin at that point.

post.author: onu
post.body:
If you want a surface to be smooth, make sure you select "smoothing" in the surface editor.

Otherwise you have to subdivide until the triangles are smaller than the pixels on the destination bump map.

Not that I ever did that... >_>

When you want hard edges to these smooth surfaces, create a new surface. Smoothing doesn't occur across surface groups, so you'll have a hard edge there even if both surfaces have smoothing turned on and they are identical in every way.

Another way to get hard edges is to simply unweld points, but that's more cumbersome to work with.

			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><span class="postbody">I've been working on becoming a modeller in lightwave for a while now and I'm having some issues with my UV Map for my shotgun I'm working on. 
<br/><br/>
I wish I had some screenshots to help, but I left them at work  <img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/images/smiles/icon_sad.gif" alt="Sad" border="0"/><br/><br/>
I'll do my best to explain. 
<br/><br/>
I made a surface (select polygons - 'q' ) out of a portion of the gun. I then proceeded to 'Make UV' etc. The selected area is cylindrical on the Z axis; I'm sure of it, so I know that's not the issue. 
<br/><br/>
I made my UV in Photoshop and saved it into my textures archive in lightwave (1024x1024 texture, jpeg, max quality). However, the second I opened it up via image editor and layed the image over the actual UV, and applied it live to the texture-view of the model, the image became extremely low-res, as in it-looks-like-its-100x100-but-stretched-to-1000x1000 low-res. Very pixelated. Also, on my image for the purpose of the model I put the text "Model Version 1.21.3" and although it is very foggy on the model, I can tell that it's .. backwards/inverted/in 'mirror code' (incoherent on the model). 
<br/><br/>
I fixed it by realizing that every square on my grid (after I turned the grid back on via display options) measured 3 feet, whereas my image was a normal 72px/". So, I resized my 12 foot shotgun into a reasonable realistic size and changed the grid. It is now about 3 feet long, each square on the grid being 1 foot. It seemed to help somewhat, but just on the verge of 'noticable difference.' 
<br/><br/>
The next thing that I did was hit 'd' again for display, and I cannot recall what tab it was under right now, but I believe it was layout. Not sure. Either way, the value was something very low, in the 60's or 70's button. I hit the '1024' button and whatever it did, it apparently worked. The image now appears to be the correct resolution on the model, and is quite clear. 
<br/><br/>
But the text is also quite clearly backwards >.^
<br/><br/>
Any help on re-doing this, or making sure all my images fit the model would be great!<br/>_________________<br/>.Mods.C++.Animation.Graphics.Doom.WebDesign.

			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><hr/></td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><span class="postbody">Well, I'm far enough to have a good number of mapobjects under my belt, but I'm no lightwave authority either.
<br/><br/>
I end up unwrapping everything manually, even simple objects, because it's the best way (that I know of) to get everything right with a minimal number of seams.
<br/><br/>
The orientation matters.  The text isn't reversed on the model, the UV just isn't oriented in the fashion you want.  I seriously believe it's Lightwave's method of unwrapping.  Using Atlas might produce better results, since it can go piece by piece that way, but then the skin will have more seams than is required.
<br/><br/>
This is why I would encourage you to start unwrapping manually.  It seems assinine for a cylinder, I know, but the more practice you get in the better off you'll be when you need to skin something more organic.
<br/><br/>
I use the method described in "approach 2" here: <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.newtek.com/products/lightwave/tutorials/uvmapping/character_UV/index.html" target="_blank" class="postlink">http://www.newtek.com/products/lightwave/tutorials/uvmapping/character_UV/index.html</a>
<br/><br/>
This method gives you total control over where the seams will be generated (important with bump mapping), as well as how much detail specific parts of your model will be relative to other parts (on a shotgun barrel, for instance, your pixels might be better spent with details along the circumference of the cylinder, as opposed to along the length).
<br/><br/>
And even if you ultimately go back to using projections for most of your UV maps, practice you get in with this method will help you be more bold when editing your UVs, and help you understand how inverted, rotated, skewed, and scaled triangles will affect your result.</span><span class="gensmall"/></td>

<br/><br/>
Totally!  I can't see your mesh in the UV view in that screenshot, but I'm assuming you might also have to scale that part of the model down.
<br/><br/>
As far as printscreening for the texture...
<br/><br/>
I assume you're making this model for Doom 3.  That's all I model for so my workflow is, as far as I know, the quickest way from nothing to in-game with lightwave.  So let me describe how I do it.  Not saying your way is wrong, I realize that's the way it's done quite often (or I guess instead of printscreen a modeler more experienced than us might make a quick render in layout using the uv map, but I don't know how to do that).
<br/><br/>
Step: The First
<br/>
Anyways, I create the High Poly mesh first.  In this mesh I assign up to six different surfaces on the model, based on how I plan to skin it later.  I have a Red, Green, and Blue surface with smoothing on (for organics), and Red, Green, and Blue surface with smoothing off (for flat surfaces and harsh angles).  There's no need to set the color to actually be red, green, and blue until you're ready to renderbump.
<br/><br/>
Step: The Second
<br/>
I create the Low Poly mesh second.  It's easy to do with the High Poly mesh in the background.  I usually just draw the triangles by hand, with the add points tool, and then selecting points and either making a triangle, quad, triangle fan, or triangle bridge.  It's not as fast as merging surfaces, or using qemLOSS2 or a lot of other ways, but it's precise and puts all the right triangles in all the right places.
<br/><br/>
Step: The Second Jr.
<br/>
I create a morph map called "flat" and proceed to unwrap my UV map here.  This method is described pretty well in that article I linked earlier.  When I'm done I use the Planar projection with manual settings.  You can usually leave the Center variables alone, but you'll probably want to modify the Size variables so that they're even (i.e. not X of 1.18 m and Y of 1.12, you'd want both to be 1.18 if you're projecting on the Z plane).
<br/><br/>
Step: His Highness the Third
<br/>
Let's review what we have.  <ol type="1"><li>A high poly mesh with a handful of different colored surfaces.</li><li>A low poly mesh with a surface that points to our material and a UV map.</li></ol>  So now we make sure the material we're pointing to has the renderbump command, with "-colormap" specified.  Go to Doom3 and renderbump <path_to_low_poly.lwo>.
<br/><br/>
This should produce a bump map and a color map in the path we specified in the shader.  In photoshop I use the bumpmap to discern where the triangles fall (this serves as my mesh view, and it's surprisingly easy to work with), and I use the color map to make quick selections of different parts so that I can, for instance, just select the red channel and use that as a mask on a layer containing a wood texture for the gun's stock, and then select the green channel and use that as a mask on a layer containing metal for the gun's barrel.
<br/><br/>
Then there's all sorts of voodoo I work for refining the skin, like my tutorial on modwiki where I base the specularmap on the bumpmap to start with.
<br/><br/>
This is the workflow that has served me best thus far.  It's a combination of Goliath's early tutorial with lightwave, id's iddevnet way, and that uv unwrapping article I linked.
<br/><br/>
Working in earnest, with my modest modeling skills, I can have a near-final model in game in a few hours this way.  Albeit, with a rudimentary skin at that point.</span><span class="gensmall"/></td>
